title: Making the connection for a seamless service experience
text:
“What would be different today if we started fresh and didn't have any legacies to deal with?”

According to Alexander, one of the keys to promoting greenfield thinking is to get the culture right and getting people to think differently, outside of the way they normally think.

“I think it is re-thinking, starting again and engaging with the people who are confronting a problem, whether it's someone receiving welfare or looking for a job, or whatever it is,” Alexander says.

Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Institutional Banking & Markets, Managing Director for Connected services, Julie Hunter agrees digital transformation is a re-engineering process and it starts with understanding the pain point the organisation is trying to solve.

“What digital technology allows us to do is to amplify the benefits of re-engineering customer journeys,” Hunter says.

In the public sector, the Digital Transformation Agency’s Head of Government Digital Experience, Lucy Poole says greenfield thinking or a “different lens” is being applied to the way the government designs services.

One particular example is how the government assists during different life events ranging from birth to education, finding a job and even end of life.

“We call it the life event lens, and ultimately it's about creating a seamless service by joining up government so that it doesn't matter which government is delivering the service. All the user sees is an efficient and effective service that they can access.

At present, the DTA is focusing on three life events with each project being led by the states and territories.

“We have a ‘having a baby’ life event project that the ACT government is leading in collaboration with the federal government, Queensland and New South Wales, a ‘finding a job’ life event being led by Queensland, and another focused on end of life being led by New South Wales,” Poole says.

As to what happens across these life events, Poole says it’s about minimising the amount of process involved by linking data between departments. For example, parents and their newborn will interact with the medical system at a number of levels as well as the birth registry and more. It’s about ensuring people have a more seamless experience in their whole of government dealings.

Alexander says: “If we can capture just one or two additional pieces of information from registering your baby with Births, Deaths, and Marriages, we can use it to seamlessly update Medicare and get your child welfare entitlements.

“It’s a marked improvement in service and what’s more, it's not just about getting the government involved.

“It expands out to the private sector, with partners like the Commonwealth Bank of Australia where with the birth of a child for example, child payments would go straight to a nominated bank account which is already known through other interactions and processes with government.

Hunter agrees this ecosystem approach allows for a much better citizen experience and the opportunities are huge.

Moreover, process changes can be quite simple, by shifting interactions away from paper and cheques to electronic payments.

She says the New Payments Platform, which is an industry-wide payments platform rolled out across the nation, is going to provide a range of new opportunities for the digital exchange of data and value. For example, an individual could receive a text that their licence is due for renewal and within one or two touches, the payment is made and the licence renewed.

“Obviously, equality of access will remain important and so individuals could still opt to receive notifications in the mail,” Hunter points out.

She says the Commonwealth Bank of Australia’s involvement in collaborating and co-designing some of these evolving government services starts at the ground level.

“For example, we can push notifications through to customers using our app about what rebates are available to them. It makes a difference in the community and enhances financial wellbeing and at present it’s working really well,” Hunter says.

“Ultimately, it's about giving consumers choice through personalisation options, and also not forgetting that digital is going to be one means.

“We will always have other channels available to people so that the most vulnerable parts of society will continue to receive services and the support that they need, when they need it,” Poole says.

And Australia is not alone in going down this path with Singapore, New Zealand, the UK as well as the United States and much of Europe starting to embrace the idea of providing touch points at significant life events.

“It’s about reducing the number of touch points with governments to the lowest possible and at the same time be a lot more sophisticated about how we use data and offer intuitive experiences,” Poole says.

“The ultimate vision is to have seamlessly integrated services that support people's needs and life events. And of course, we achieve that through collaboration with our state and territory colleagues as well as other industry sectors and organisations like the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.”

It’s all part of a much broader Connected Services ecosystem which can deliver solutions to many of a society’s pain points beyond the individual such as transport solutions where small fintech players as well as big technology companies and major infrastructure players can work together.

And it would seem banks are integral to connected services because together with government, “they pretty much provide the foundational underpinning of everything that happens in an economy,” Hunter concludes.
description: The world sits at a turning point in its digital transformation.
